page.title: 01Mid-Weardale.
page.content: The area is characterised by a deep valley with fell-land on either side. At the north-eastern corner of the area is the only village,Stanhope, situated by the River Wear. Although Stanhope Church has a Norman foundation, the major development of Stanhope occurred in the nineteenth century when lead mining was very important to the area. Further expansion took place in the later half of this century with the opening of a cement works further up the Dale,using the local minerals. The lead mines are now closed but their spoil heaps are still in evidence, but now grassed over and used for grazing. The rest of the area is devoted to agriculture,mostly sheep-farming, but there is some stock fattening.
